It is during this fellowship that he would have begun to focus his expertise on multiple myeloma, a complex and challenging malignancy of plasma cells. His diagnostic expertise would encompass the interpretation of various laboratory tests, including complete blood counts, serum protein electrophoresis, immunofixation electrophoresis, and bone marrow biopsies. He would be skilled in identifying abnormal plasma cells, detecting monoclonal proteins, and assessing the extent of bone marrow involvement. He would also be proficient in using imaging techniques, such as X-rays, CT scans, and MRI, to evaluate bone lesions and assess disease progression.

Dr. Kumar's clinical skills would extend to the management of various complications associated with multiple myeloma, including anemia, bone pain, kidney dysfunction, and infections. He would be adept at prescribing and monitoring medications, such as chemotherapy agents, immunomodulatory drugs, and proteasome inhibitors. He would also be experienced in providing supportive care, such as blood transfusions, pain management, and infection control.

His involvement in multiple myeloma trials indicates a deep understanding of clinical trial design, methodology, and regulatory requirements.
